Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes and consequences of regular spatial patterning in foundation species: theoretical development and experimental tests in an African savanna
Award.AbstractNarration:
New satellite imagery has revealed that many natural ecological systems form surprisingly uniform patterns. This project will advance our understanding about how these patterns form and how they affect resources such as water and nutrients and the abundance and distribution of plants and animals. Research will combine experimental field studies in tropical savanna in Kenya with mathematical modeling to investigate the causes and consequences of the regular pattern of large mounds formed over wide areas by soil-dwelling termites. Researchers will investigate the physical and biological mechanisms that space termite colonies, and how the mounded landscape shapes food webs and determines overall productivity and stability of the system.

This project is expected to add to the scientific basis for managing rangeland ecosystems, where self-organized patterns may be important indicators of ecological degradation and components of landscape restoration. Project data will be made freely available to the public. The project will also contribute to science education in multiple ways. A post-doctoral researcher and a number of undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, will participate first-hand in the field research. Many more students will benefit from new instructional units based on the research and added to the curricula at the home universities of the researchers in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A striking feature shared by many natural ecosystems and human-built environments is their regular spatial organization. In environments engineered by people, regularities are often the result of premeditated design to serve particular functions. For example, the arrangement of city blocks in rectangular grids facilitates orientation, navigation, and efficient development. In natural ecosystems, the arrangement of elements can be just as regular. Labyrinths, rings, and evenly spaced polka dots of vegetation are common in deserts and grasslands worldwide, sometimes stretching over enormous distances. Yet the causes and functions of these patterns are largely unknown.

Our research addressed two major questions: how do regular patterns form in ecosystems, and how do these patterns matter for the functioning of the ecosystem? To answer these questions, we combined mathematical theory, experiments, molecular biology, and comparative observations of spatially patterned ecosystems. We focused primarily on two mechanisms that might generate regular patterns. First, plants can in principle self-organize in response to water availability, which can lead to labyrinths, gaps, and spots. Second, 'ecosystem engineers' such as ground-nesting ants and termites locally enhance plant growth on or around their nests; these nests are often separated by a characteristic distance, leading to regularly spaced spots or rings of vegetation, perhaps because neighboring colonies compete for resources. These two mechanisms are debated as alternative explanations for various large-scale vegetation patterns, such as the astonishing 'fairy circles' of the Namib Desert.

Using mathematical models in conjunction with real-world field measurements, we reconciled these two mechanisms, showing that competition between termite colonies typically generates patterns with a larger length scale (nests separated by tens of meters), whereas the self-organization of grasses tends to produce smaller-scale patterns (with length scales of centimeters). These smaller-scale patterns -- predicted by our theoretical model and subsequently confirmed by field observations in Kenya and Namibia -- had not previously been documented. Our work showed that rather than being alternatives, these two mechanisms can be complementary; they simply operate at different scales. This research provides a firm theoretical foundation for the multi-scale vegetation patterns found in the Namib Desert fairy circles and helps to resolve longstanding debates over the origins of mysterious vegetation patterns worldwide. 

We built on this work with empirical studies showing that termites from neighboring colonies in a Kenyan savanna do indeed fight fiercely (validating a premise of our theory) and that nests in areas with more abundant resources remain regularly spaced but are more densely packed (as expected if nest spacing is driven by competition for resources). By adapting our mathematical model of competition-driven pattern formation, we explored the factors that determine the degree of regularity in termite nest distributions, showing that underlying heterogeneity in resource availability modulates the regularity of the patterns that emerge.

But are these natural patterns just pretty pictures and biological curiosities, or do they actually matter for the healthy functioning of ecosystems? Our research shows that they do matter. In savannas, upon which millions of people depend for livelihood, termite mounds buffer ecosystems against the effects of climate extremes: ecosystems with termite mounds are both less likely to lose vegetation during a drought and quicker to regain vegetation after a drought. Moreover, the regular patterning of termite mounds increases the overall productivity of the ecosystem: a savanna with regularly patterned termite mounds will support more abundant vegetation and more wildlife and livestock than a savanna with the same number of termite mounds arranged in a random fashion. The regular patterning of termite mounds also generates regular patterning -- and greater diversity -- of soil microbes and their crucial ecological functions. 

We synthesized this research in a review article that summarized the current state of knowledge and outlined an agenda for future work on how multiple mechanisms interact to generate regular patterns and on the ways in which these patterns matter.

Collectively, the work described above deepens our understanding of how the unplanned, self-organizing behavior of plants and animals causes ecosystems to look and function the way they do. We now know that these behaviors and ecosystem-engineering species are important for the health and stability of ecosystems in the face of rapid environmental change, both natural and human-caused. And this research may yet hold lessons that help us understand the organization of human societies, past and present. Whereas many aspects of human-engineered systems are planned and premeditated, others emerge as a product of the localized actions of millions of individuals with no grand plan and little knowledge of the individuals acting around them -- not unlike termites.
